explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is 215degC (open cup flash test) (NFPA (13th, 2002))

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 390degC (NFPA, 13th, 2002)).

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 32,100mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 30,000mg/kg, 53,700mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002)), 47,000mg/kg (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2005)) and 34,000mg/kg (PATTY (4th, 1999)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the guinea pig LD50 (dermal route) value of 4,890mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: The results of human patch tests suggest no evidence of skin irritation (CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002)), whereas MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2005) provides some evidence of skin irritation in humans: "Dermal application of dioctyl phthalate (details of the isomer unknown) produced skin irritation and sensitization in human volunteers." These inconsistent results do not allow the presence or absence of skin irritation to be determined, and thus classification is not possible.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: No data available An epidemiological study reports that occupational exposure to phthalic acids (including di-n-octyl phthalate in the gaseous form) showed irritation of the eye and upper respiratory tract (CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002)).

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitizer: Category 1 Skin sensitizer: Category 1
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: No data available An epidemiological study provides evidence of respiratory sensitization in humans (CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002)): "workers occupationally exposed to dioctyl phthalate (structural details unknown) exhibited asthmatic responses." Skin sensitizer: Based on the description in the report on epidemiological studies of human exposure (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2005)): "Dermal application of dioctyl phthalate (details of the isomer missing) produced skin irritation and sensitization in human volunteers."

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ/somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ/somatic cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and no positive data on mutagenicity tests in vitro (several indices), described in CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002), ATSDR (1997) and NTP DB (Access on April 2006).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible based on expert judgment in the absence of existing classification, though CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002) provides some toxicity data.

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based on the evidence of decreased number of live borns at doses at which parental toxicity is unknown in mouse teratogenicity studies, described in MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2005) and ATSDR (1997).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Insufficient data available
CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002) provides evidence of acute effects of di-n-octyl phthalate in humans: "workers occupationally exposed to dioctyl phthalate (structural details unknown) exhibited asthmatic responses."

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since it was suggested from 96-hour LC50>20mg/L of the fish (Oryzias Latipest) (MOE Eco-Toxicity Tests of Chemicals, 1997) that relevant toxicity is not indicated in the water solubility (0.022mg/L(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)) of this substance, it was classified into Not classified.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although it is water-insolubility and acute toxicity was not reported within the aqueous solubility concentrations and there was the bio-accumulation (log Kow=8.1(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was the rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 67% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Not classified.
